abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            and project sustainability is regarded as likely. World Bank
            performance is evaluated as unsatisfactory, while Borrower
            performance is judged as satisfactory. These were some of
            the lessons learned: 1) Successfully creating a market-based
            seed production and distribution system in place of a
            centrally-based system requires the gradual involvement of
            the private sector. 2) see production should be based on a
            thorough assessment of farmer demand and market for improved
            varieties, not just focusing on supply. 3) Substantial
            changes to the project design should not be made without
            fully analyzing the proposed design in terms of economic,
            financial, and social impacts and ensuring that the new
            approach is sustainable. 4) to ensure better implementation,
            arrangements for monitoring and evaluation need to be in
            place before the project starts. 5) To ensure continuity and
            sustainability, planning and initiating transitional
            arrangements well in advance of project closure (some 18
            months) is necessary. 6) Single factor projects are unlikely
            to have a major impact on agricultural production. 7)
            Government commitment is critical for the timely
            finalization of project preparation. 8) Assess the impact of
            an evolving situation and act quickly: the project failed to
            assess the impact of a rapidly expanding approach which
            relied on a single market outlet under the national
            extension intervention program on the project. It also
            failed to act decisively in response to these changes.
